fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(14, 8), constrained_layout=True)

)

    .value_counts()
    .reindex(yesmaybeno_order)
)

def getsubpercentage(valuecount):
    total = valuecount.sum()
    return [f"{(subgroup / total * 100):.1f}%" for subgroup in valuecount]
#to get fstrings for percentage of each subgroup to 1 d.p
#creating a function because I may need later

general_interest_percentage = getsubpercentage(general_app_interest)
paid_interest_percentage = getsubpercentage(paid_app_interest)

gen_bargraph = ax1.bar(general_app_interest.index, general_app_interest.values, color=yesnomaybe_colours)
ax1.set_title('Interest in a Hearing Health App', fontsize = 8)

From Fig.1, while nearly 81% of respondents (combined 'Yes' and 'Maybe') demonstrate initial openness to a hearing health app, interest seems highly price-sensitive. Specifically, interest drops sharply from 34.9% to 12.1% for the "Yes" group when a cost is introduced. Interestingly, the 'Maybe' segment remained stable at \~50%, suggesting a "wait-and-see" market that likely requires a stronger value proposition. Given the high general interest but low immediate willingness to pay, a freemium strategy (e.g. free screening with paid advanced features) is likely the most viable path for adoption.
